Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Lots of timeouts when downloading the package in catalog2dnx" (#5476) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
AI query:

```
traces
| where timestamp > ago(90d) 
| extend jobName = tostring(customDimensions.JobName) 
| where severityLevel > 2
| where message contains "TaskCanceledException" and message contains "LoadNuspec" 
| summarize sum(itemCount) by cloud_RoleInstance, jobName, bin(timestamp, 1d)
| render timechart 
```

In the past 90 days:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/36181596-53aa55aa-10da-11e8-9194-d59869d628ce.png)

The reason I discovered this is because the China catalog2dnx job was stuck because it could not download the following package in within the timeout (the default `HttpClient` timeout of 100 seconds): CenterSpace.NMath.Premium 6.2.0.40. This package is over 200 MB.

Another thing I noticed on my own machine was that the CDN download was much slower than the download directly from blob storage. We could consider going to blob storage directly. This also means we don't need the cache busting behavior.

Also note that feed2catalog also downloads the .nupkg but has not had any of the timeout exceptions. The only timeout exceptions have been from feed2catalog on the prod-v3jobs-1 VM.

We should increase this timeout and make it configurable much like the timeout on China upload operations.

/cc @agr @cristinamanum

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Determine minimal set of flat-container validations to implement" (#3768) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: The result of this task should be an ordered list of validations against flat-container. As part of this, set up a brainstorming with the team.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGetGallery P1 functional test "PackagesPageTest" is flaky" (#3676) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: It compares the download count on search service with download count on the gallery and assumes they match. This is not necessarily true.

This tool must have the ability to
- read the versions index
- download and parse the `.nupkg`s

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Install command on package description page" (#3473) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
On npmjs.org, the details page shows the command to install the package:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3840695/21967742/23c2b786-db95-11e6-9f5c-af66064c3fe8.png)


On nuget.org, the details page also shows us the install command like this:

---
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3840695/21967774/ce6f88b2-db95-11e6-8a49-17e683a1917f.png)
---

However, the command:

```powershell
Install-Package System.Net.Http 
```

only works in Visual Studio's Package Manager Console.

It would be great to have a more general command in instruction, which works across the board, instead of or in addition to the existing one:

```cmd
nuget install System.Net.Http
```

or

```cmd
nuget install System.Net.Http -source https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Misleading Wiki page about self-hosting" (#3462) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
On step 13 of this page: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/wiki/Hosting-the-NuGet-Gallery-Locally-in-IIS, it says to update **dbo.GlobalSettings** to match your desired configuration.  With this migration, 201302072118537_MovingGallerySettingsToConfiguration, it looks like columns from that table were dropped to prefer a web.config based configuration.

Should this be updated to say something like this?

13) Update the appropriate Web.Config appSettings to match your desired SMTP/Email and Branding settings

I spent a few minutes tripping over this to find that the GlobalSettings table is no longer intended for email configuration.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Unit tests for search service Lucene directories" (#3411) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Closed issue "Add UTs to NuGet.Jobs jobs" (#3402) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: The unit tests for the jobs in `NuGet.Jobs` are minimal and not very extensive. We should have many more unit tests, and the tests themselves should be extensive.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Search service memory issue" (#3372) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Search service suffers from memory issues.
The process reaches 12GB of memory consumption before GC collection is initiated, on machines with 14GB of memory.
This causes IIS to stop functioning, and the service is shutdown.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Stress tests in INT should predict production search service memory issues" (#3371) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: One way to repro the memory issues prod suffers from in INT, is to increase the number of packages in INT.

Events.RelatedBody: [With geo-redundant status](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/6119), it is no longer necessary to prefer any region over the other (e.g. Priority).

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Stats - Monitor activity of W3C log collector" (#3248) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Network connectivity issues can cause the Stats.CollectAzureCdnLogs job to no longer pick-up W3C logs delivered by the CDN.
We need to monitor this and raise an alert when appropriate.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Add pack extension point for including debug symbols" (#7234) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
`TargetsForTfmSpecificBuildOutput` can't be used to add supplementary .pdb files to only the "symbols.nupkg" file.

Please add an extension point like `TargetsForTfmSpecificDebugSymbolsOutput`.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Setup the new credential provider for dotnet nuget push" (#7233) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: Add credential providers support to the dotnet nuget push command.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Clarify that props and targets assets will not be imported through transitive dependencies" (#7226) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
@geeeyetee commented on [Tue Jul 31 2018](https://github.com/NuGet/docs.microsoft.com-nuget/issues/997)

The phrase "_as can projects that consume AppLogger_" in the following sentence is incomplete and may mislead some developers.

> AppLogger can consume the targets and props from Contoso.Utility.UsefulStuff, as can projects that consume AppLogger.

The sentence is in the section "_Controlling dependency assets_" on the "_Package references (PackageReference) in project files_" page. The following references detail the fact that targets and props can be made to `Import` to projects that directly consume a package, but not to projects that indirectly (transitively) consume a package.

- https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/6934 "_Transitive PackageReference packages do not contribute build logic_"
- https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/6091 "_Change the default behavior of build dependency asset to transitive_"

---
#### Document Details

⚠ *Do not edit this section. It is required for docs.microsoft.com ➟ GitHub issue linking.*

* ID: ff707668-94d6-25a5-9139-b18cc1b6b446
* Version Independent ID: 494847b9-4894-0beb-7ffa-39a2359999fa
* Content: [NuGet PackageReference format (package references in project files)](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/consume-packages/package-references-in-project-files#controlling-dependency-assets)
* Content Source: [docs/consume-packages/Package-References-in-Project-Files.md](https://github.com/NuGet/docs.microsoft.com-nuget/blob/master/docs/consume-packages/Package-References-in-Project-Files.md)
* Product: **nuget**
* GitHub Login: @karann-msft
* Microsoft Alias: **karann**

---

@nkolev92 commented on [Tue Jul 31 2018](https://github.com/NuGet/docs.microsoft.com-nuget/issues/997#issuecomment-409311468)

This is only by default. 
Package authors can build packages correctly to make their packages bring in the transitive dependencies. 

---

@geeeyetee commented on [Tue Jul 31 2018](https://github.com/NuGet/docs.microsoft.com-nuget/issues/997#issuecomment-409339790)

@nkolev92 - How can a project **`Import`** a `.props` or `.targets` file that is contained in a transitively-referenced `PackageReference`?

EDIT
My understanding is that the "by default" aspect concerns inclusion of the `.props` and `.targets` in the `.nupkg`. The article does cover how to overcome that. However, a consuming project will will only reference those files in `Import` elements when the package is a directly-included `PackageReference`-- there is no way to make that happen when the package is indirectly/transitively included.

---

@nkolev92 commented on [Tue Jul 31 2018](https://github.com/NuGet/docs.microsoft.com-nuget/issues/997#issuecomment-409340942)

Say you have the following:

Project 1 -> Package A -> Package B, where Package B has targets. 

When building Package A, the author of Package A can choose to allow the Package targets to flow transitively. 

Package A could be built with Package B as a reference like this:
> <PackageReference Include="B" PrivateAssets="content;analyzers"/>

The default PrivateAssets value is `build;content;analyzers` per https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/consume-packages/package-references-in-project-files#controlling-dependency-assets

That would preserve that information in the nuspec of Package A when packed. 

Then the consumer of Package A will be happy. 

Note that the options are more limited when it comes to the Package A consumer. 

---

@geeeyetee commented on [Tue Jul 31 2018](https://github.com/NuGet/docs.microsoft.com-nuget/issues/997#issuecomment-409343119)

@nkolev92 - Thanks for your reply-- it crossed path with my "EDIT" above. Please let me know if that clarification makes sense to you and let me know if it is correct. Based on my own experience/testing and research over the last couple of days, I believe it is.

---

@geeeyetee commented on [Tue Jul 31 2018](https://github.com/NuGet/docs.microsoft.com-nuget/issues/997#issuecomment-409343830)

So in your example, if `PrivateAssets` is set to `none` Project 1 will theoretically have access to the targets files, but it will not import them.

---

@geeeyetee commented on [Tue Jul 31 2018](https://github.com/NuGet/docs.microsoft.com-nuget/issues/997#issuecomment-409344123)

... whereas the project for  Package A will import the targets.

---

@nkolev92 commented on [Tue Jul 31 2018](https://github.com/NuGet/docs.microsoft.com-nuget/issues/997#issuecomment-409345158)

>  Project 1 will theoretically have access to the targets files, but it will not import them.
I wouldn't say it has access, but you are correct, it won't import them. 

---

@bording commented on [Tue Jul 31 2018](https://github.com/NuGet/docs.microsoft.com-nuget/issues/997#issuecomment-409350983)

>I wouldn't say it has access, but you are correct, it won't import them.

@nkolev92 Are you sure about that? I've definitely authored a package that has package references with `PrivateAssets=none`, and when projects consume that package, they definitely get the props/targets of the transitively referenced packages in their nuget.g.props/nuget.g.targets files.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "dotnet pack removes nuget range if floating version is used" (#7232) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @Kieranties on August 22, 2018 9:39_

## Steps to reproduce
Create a project and add a reference to a nuget package, floating on the patch, but within a range.
e.g. `<PackageReference Include="microsoft.aspnetcore.app" Version="[2.1.*, 2.3.0)" />`

## Expected  behavior
When running `dotnet pack` the latest patch version is restored and the range is honored in the nuspec.
E.g. if the latest patch is version `2.1.3`, the nuspec would contain:
`<dependency id="microsoft.aspnetcore.app" version="[2.1.3, 3.0.0)" exclude="Build,Analyzers" />`

## Actual behavior
The latest patch is restored, however the range in the nuspec is removed:
`<dependency id="microsoft.aspnetcore.app" version="2.1.3" exclude="Build,Analyzers" />`

The same issue is seen when floating on the pre-release, e.g. `2.1.3-*`

## Environment data
`dotnet --info` output:
```
> dotnet --info
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "msbuild restore problem with feed with apiKey" (#7231) at NuGet/Home

we have nuget.config with 3 feed 
1) nuget.org
2) ravendb ci

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Feature request: Specifying a .csproj file for nuget spec command" (#7230) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet product used: nuget.exe
NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 4.6.2.5055 (Is what I'm currently using, but this feature isn't listed in the documentation so I assume no version has had it.)

The documentation says that if you run `nuget spec` in a folder where there is a `.csproj` file it will automatically create a `.nuspec` file for it. However, it doesn't say if there's a way to specify a specific `.csproj` file, so I can only assume that there isn't one. Thus, I'm requesting such a feature.

Being able to specify a specific `.csproj` file would help in at least these two situations:
1. If the `.csproj` file is in a different folder than where you're running the `nuget spec` command.
2. If there's more than one `.csproj` file in the same folder. (Don't question it, I've seen it multiple times.)

I'll try to explain what I want in detail.

Assume I have a folder structure like this:
MyProject
L Build
| L build.bat
L NuGet
L myProject.csproj

I run build.bat which somewhere contains the command
`nuget spec ..\myProject.csproj -Force -OutputDirectory ..\NuGet\`
(nuget spec doesn't currently have the -OutputDirectory option, but I've written a separate feature request for that (https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7229). Bear with me.)
**..\myProject.csproj** is the important part specific to this feature request.

The resulting folder structure should be like this:
MyProject
L Build
| L build.bat
L NuGet
| L myProject.nuspec
L myProject.csproj

I hope my explanation was clear enough.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Feature request: -OutputDirectory option for the nuget spec command." (#7229) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet product used: nuget.exe

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 4.6.2.5055 (Is what I'm currently using, but according to the documentation no version has this feature.)

I wrote an issue on the documentation where I asked if it was possible to designate an output path for the `nuget spec` command and I was told that there wasn't (https://github.com/NuGet/docs.microsoft.com-nuget/issues/999). So I'm requesting such a feature.

I'll try to explain what I want in detail.

Assume I have a folder structure like this:
MyProject\
L Build\
|  L build.bat
L NuGet\
L myProject.csproj

I run build.bat which somewhere contains the command
`nuget spec ..\myProject.csproj -Force -OutputDirectory ..\NuGet\`
(nuget spec doesn't currently have the ability to specify a .csproj file like this, but I intend to write a separate feature request for that. Bear with me.)
**-OutputDirectory ..\NuGet\\** is the important part specific to this feature request.

The resulting folder structure should be like this:
MyProject\
L Build\
|  L build.bat
L NuGet\
|  L myProject.nuspec
L myProject.csproj

I hope my explanation was clear enough.

I specifically chose "OutputDirectory" instead of, say, "Output" or "OutputDir" because it's the same as the option which the `nuget pack` command has.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Broken Push: Error 400 (There must be exactly one package.)" (#7228) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): NuGet.exe
NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 4.7.1, 4.8.1
dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate):
VS version (if appropriate): 
OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): win10
Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: 3.4.4

I am trying to push packages (with NuGet 4.7.1) to ProGet (5.1.5) with the nuget.exe. It is hosted on an linux docker container. I am always getting an error 400 (There must be exactly one package.). 

There are other people with the same [issue](https://inedo.com/support/questions/reply/4511) and the workaround is to use NuGet 3.4.4. I tried that and voila: It works like a charm. Every Push is a success.

For examination, I tried to put an nginx in front of ProGet. The interesting thing is that it now works "sometimes". The most cases are also error 400 (Bad Request) but sometimes the package is pushed. In the error logs the 400 occures because `client sent invalid chunked body,`.

I tried the same on an Windows Installation of ProGet and the same behavior can be observed.

What has changed from NuGet v3.4.4 to 3.5.0? The current workaround is to create packages with 4.7.x and push them with 3.4.4.

In [6691](https://inedo.com/support/questions/6691) a user is talking about problems with mono on the server side but the same problems are occuring on windows.

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Use ProGet docker container
2. Publish Package with 

````sh
.\nuget.exe push Package.3.0.0-dev001611.nupkg "API:KEY" -Source "http://url-to-proget/nuget/FEED/" -Verbosity detailed
````
...

## Other suggested things

### Verbose Logs

```
NuGet Version: 4.8.0.5278
Pushing Package.3.0.0-dev001611.nupkg to http://url-to-proget/nuget/FEED/'...
  PUT http://url-to-proget/nuget/FEED/
  BadRequest http://url-to-proget/nuget/FEED/ 119ms
Response status code does not indicate success: 400 (There must be exactly one package.).
System.Net.Http.HttpRequestException: Response status code does not indicate success: 400 (There must be exactly one pac
kage.).
   at System.Net.Http.HttpResponseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCode()
   at NuGet.Protocol.Core.Types.PackageUpdateResource.<>c.<PushPackageToServer>b__18_0(HttpResponseMessage response)
   at NuGet.Protocol.HttpSource.<ProcessResponseAsync>d__18`1.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.Protocol.Core.Types.PackageUpdateResource.<PushPackageToServer>d__18.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.Protocol.Core.Types.PackageUpdateResource.<PushPackageCore>d__15.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.Protocol.Core.Types.PackageUpdateResource.<PushPackage>d__14.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.Protocol.Core.Types.PackageUpdateResource.<Push>d__10.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.Commands.PushRunner.<Run>d__0.MoveNext()
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
   at System.Runtime.ExceptionServices.ExceptionDispatchInfo.Throw()
   at System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
   at NuGet.CommandLine.PushCommand.<ExecuteCommandAsync>d__32.MoveNext()
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Pack command does nothing" (#7227) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
@irongut commented on [Sun Jul 22 2018](https://github.com/NuGet/docs.microsoft.com-nuget/issues/987)

The Pack command does nothing except tell me my build is up to date. Only if I Clean the solution first will the Pack command actually create a Nuget package. Since any library will have been built at least once during testing this is very annoying behaviour and the workaround is not obvious for anyone who hasn't experienced the issue before.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Show source repository information for packages on nuget.org" (#30) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
The spec to **Show source repository information for packages on nuget.org** , is ready for **review**:

|Spec wiki|Discussion issue|
|:----------|:------------------|
|[Show source repository information for packages on nuget.org](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/Show-source-repository-information-for-packages-on-nuget.org) | https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4941 |

**Note**: This is a short term feature to just light up the repository information on nuget.org using the `<repository>`  metadata in the nuspec. We plan to revisit the detailed functionality, in future.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet.org accepts signed packages" (#26) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody: Starting today May, 22nd 2018.  NuGet.org accepts signed packages. More information in the [blog post](https://blog.nuget.org/20180522/Introducing-signed-package-submissions.html)

Tweets.Text: https://t.co/F9kiKfdOWi has started to repo sign all the packages (a step closer to tamper proofing the entire pack… https://t.co/UlUHNBmedF
